title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. This Act is cited as SEC. 30B. Private Land Conservation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act allows eligible farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit equal to 10 percent of the amount that would be allowed as a deduction for a qualified conservation contribution. The maximum credit for any taxable year is $360,000. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to the taxpayer's aggregate amount for the 15 prior taxable years. Joint returns allocate the credit equally between spouses. Controlled group members are subject to an aggregation rule. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to the taxpayer's aggregate amount for the 15 prior taxable years. Controlled group members are subject to an aggregation rule where all members of the same controlled group of corporations and persons under common control are treated as 1 taxpayer. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by the sum of other allowable credits. The tax credit under the Private Land Conservation Tax Act is limited to the taxpayer's aggregate amount for the 15 prior taxable years. Eligible farmers or ranchers must meet specific income criteria to qualify for the credit. The Private Land Conservation Tax Act provides a tax credit for eligible farmers or ranchers. To qualify, the corporation's gross income from farming must be 60% or more, stock not publicly traded, and farming assets value not exceeding $20,000,000. Taxpayers must elect this section for the taxable year, and the election is irrevocable. The tax credit for qualified conservation contributions is irrevocable once elected. No deduction under section 170 is allowed for taxpayers who elect the credit. Excess credit can be carried forward to future taxable years. The tax credit for qualified conservation contributions is irrevocable once elected, and no deduction under section 170 is allowed for taxpayers who elect the credit. Any excess credit can be carried forward to future taxable years. Private land conservation amendments apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment date. An increase in the charitable contribution limit is provided for farmers and ranchers operating in corporate form. The amendment allows qualified farmers and ranchers to be treated as individuals for charitable contribution purposes. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Expansion of estate tax exclusion for land under qualified conservation easement, effective for estates of decedents dying after enactment of this Act.
